We are aware that many families may be experiencing a reduction or loss of income due to the pandemic closures in our community & state. Please know that the Oxford Community School District continues to accept applications for Free and Reduced-Price School Meal benefits until June. You can apply online at https://www.lunchapp.com/.

The benefit will be $5.70 per day per child, for each of your family members 18 years of age or younger, or enrolled in a special education program 26 years of age or younger.

We strongly encourage you to apply if your family situation has changed, or you have not applied in the past. Please contact karen.bissett@oxfordschools.org for further information or questions.

Together, with community volunteers, we are again packing 1,200 meal bags (each with enough food for one week) to distribute to the families of our Free and Reduced Lunch program students on Wednesday, April 22.

If you are experiencing the heartbreaking reality of not being able to provide food for your family during these difficult times, but your child is not on the Free and Reduced lunch list, please come anyway. We want to help you. We will distribute all of the food we have to those who need it, first come first serve, until it is gone.

Food will be available for pick-up at OMS (10:30 am- 11:30 pm door #12) and OHS from (10:30 am - 12:00 pm at the north flag pole off of Ray Rd.) We plan to continue the food distribution every Wednesday during these times and at these locations until June 3. For the safety of our volunteers, please have your rear hatch opened before they pull up to the food pick up.

Together, we will make it through this.

The Oxford RoboCats, Team 2137, has teamed up with Romeo's Byting Bulldogs to help produce headbands to support clear safety shields for hospital workers and first responders. Members of the team, mentors, and community members have been 3D printing these headbands around the clock.

Although the robotics season was cut short before they had a chance to compete, it has not hindered their resolve and willingness to help those around them. There is a need in the community and this group has stepped up again to fill that need.

To date, they have donated well over 2,300 of the headbands that go along with the face shields.

Way to Go, Robocats! You are certainly living out your mantra, "We build more than robots."

üöå An electric bus helps not only reduce air pollution, but it also reduces noise pollution compared to a diesel or gas bus.

üöå The fuel cost for a diesel bus is four times more expensive than an electric bus.

üöå The only operating noise you can hear while an electric bus is idling is the low din of the heater (when it is cold enough to have on.) An electric bus actually has a chime that sounds when it moves between 1 and 8 miles per hour to alert pedestrians and other drivers of its movement because it is so quiet.

Are you aware of the upcoming road construction on M-24?

Portions of M-24, including the stretch that runs through Downtown Oxford, will be replaced beginning in March and running through November of 2020.

The last time M-24 was completely reconstructed was nearly 100 years ago and the road is in dire need of updating.

Once the project is fully underway, it will affect how long it takes everyone to get around town including our buses.

Check out Superintendent Throne's latest podcast with Fire Chief Pete Scholz and Jim Sharpe from Sharpe Engineering to hear more: https://soundcloud.com/oxford-schools-890524034/ocs-podcast-ep-3

For information and updates on the upcoming road project see:
https://www.thevillageofoxford.org/current___upcoming_projects/road_project_updates.php

OHS and OMS Cybersecurity teams had their first competitions of the year!

After the six-hour competition, OMS Team 1 cinched the first place position in Michigan, ranking 16% in the nation among the 772 competing teams and OMS Team 2 tied for third place, ranking 27% in the nation.

OHS students improved their national ranking from last year's 50% up to 31% in the country taking 767th place out of the 2,495 teams competing across the nation!

Excellent work by OHS ninth-grade student Charlie Fracker who took second place for the production of Wildcat Gold, a short film entered into the ONTV's Wildwood Film Festival!

This is Charlie's third year competing in the challenge. He won first place in the youth category his first year, and for the past two years he has competed in the adult category (17+) and earned second place each time.

All of the students pictured below are OHS ninth-graders who worked together to write, film, star in, and edit the piece. From left to right: Ryan Shick, Jake Olheiser, Charlie Fracker, Keegan Upham, and Zach Cabanillas. Way to go, Wildcats!

Here is a link to the award-winning short film:
https://youtu.be/LBvV9FdbiKc
